Award.AwardTitle: SAVI: GECAT-Global Initiative to Enhance Collaborative Computing and Analysis Tools

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Major scientific research initiatives and enterprises are global in nature, requiring national cyberinfrastructure capabilities to not only be interoperable worldwide but to be designed to support collaborations spanning national boundaries. Collective knowledge and skills of teams is increasingly required to solve the key technical and scientific issues facing us today. In order to realize continued scientific discovery in the United States, international collaboration in interoperable forms of large-scale distributed computing, access to remote data, development of collaboration technologies and skill sets are required. Many scientific projects are international in scope, necessitating collaboration across borders, including the coordination of resources . International collaborations to construct telescopes with associated virtual observatories (such as LSST, DES and SKA), particle detectors (such as ATLAS and CMS for the Large Hadron Collider), climate (IPCC) and biological and environmental data repositories are already underway.

This project supports international virtual research organizations (IVROs) that promote and enable efficient collaboration and co-operation of researchers and developers in multiple countries. It aims to seed the development of new, innovative cyberinfrastructure features enabling international scientific collaboration for scientific advances. It builds on existing relationships and activities previously established by the PIs and institution. The project directly supports the participation of multiple U.S .participants (senior and junior faculty, postdoctoral fellows, graduate students) in workshops, and to interact, communicate, and collaborate in small research and development "seed" projects with international partners from multiple countries in Europe and Asia. The project provides an annual series of forums for publicly sharing cutting-edge research, education and training experiences covering all aspects of cyberinfrastructure, including distributed data management, system resilience, performance issues with scaling, efficient mechanisms for training and support. The project focuses on the development and study of strong International Virtual Research Organizations promoting interoperability of national cyberinfrastructures for international research. These IVROs are intended to facilitate defining and developing strategies and action plans for collaborative projects, and activities leading to the availability of high end middleware tools, and interoperability of national cyberinfrastructures for addressing and resolving grand science challenges through advancing cyberinfrastructure and computational science.

This is designated as a Science Across Virtual Institutes (SAVI) award and is co-funded by NSF's Office of International and Integrative Activities and the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engieering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
International Virtual Research Organizations (IVRO) for multidisciplinary collaborative research can be very effective in increasing the impact and productivity of research teams.  IVROs are built upon cyberinfrastructure providing a complex system of organizing, planning, and decision making for scientific research. IVRO initiatives combine people, complex data systems, scientific instruments, and other technologies to support scientific activities, communication and coordination among partner organizations. Decision making related to organizational structures and processes provide challenges for the managers of IVROs as this decision making process has a direct relation to decision success and IVROimpact. Because of the complexity of IVROs, it seems obvious that strategic decisions should be made according to structured approaches, and that evolution of the structure will be necessary to ensure IVRO success.

In evaluating IVROs we noted similarities and differences across different structures. There are also various types of challenges and each IVRO tackle challenge is its own way. An IVRO is the product of multiple decisions related to management, scientific activities, technological design, participation, communication, and coordination. The IVRO community is varied and, based on the mission and vision of an IVRO, it is composed of a set of stakeholders that can include scientists, developers, funders, support personnel, and participating scientific organizations, among others. IRVOs have differing levels of formality in their structures and governance and that the relative levels of influence of various sets of stakeholders are also different among IVROs. Despite challenges, IVROs have great potentials to advance the objectives of their scientific communities. Further understanding the influence of structural factors through variations across IVROs would enable us to make them more effective. Some overarching observations are:

Membership – Having a very governance document such as a memorandum of understanding (MoU) that details relationships, responsibilities, management structures, participation, and activities helps to assure common understanding among the parties and increases IVRO impact.

Management and coordination - There are two levels of goals for IVROs. Operational goals denote goals related to the scientific enterprise that the IVRO supports, while broader impact goals include educational activities, influencing national or global policies, and building communities of scholars and practitioners. IVRO management and coordination should be organized to achieve these goals. Organizational structures dedicated to administration and to managing the scientific/research activities are two different structural sets within IVRO organizing. Administrative activities include organizational leadership, management, and external relations and often include bodies such as steering committees, while work groups are examples of how scientific and research activities are managed. The IVROs that have some funded management leaders and facilitators seem to be more productive and larger.

Communication and participation - All IVROs observed during this project had an online presence that were used for information and document sharing. Distributed version control and source code management systems such as Git were used to manage collaboratively developed tools and applications. All three IVROs observed under our investigation are built around annual or bi-annual workshops as major venue for idea generation, discussion, sharing and progress management. Almost all significant management decisions are made during these meetings, where most collaboration is done face-to-face. Management participants and workgroup members utilize workshop time to discuss major issues, organizing, negotiation, and future directions. Participation of individual scholars, scientists, and technologies mostly depends upon the relationship between their parent organization and the IVRO.

Activities and outputs - The nature of IVRO products depends upon the mission and vision of the organization. Activities within IVROs are related to the product they have in mind. Some have projects that are product driven with formal agreements. Others emphasize academic exchanges. All IVRO websites provide presentations and meeting notes.

Some final work and studies planned for the last year of this effort were preempted by COVID-19 Pandemic.
